byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon and Alison Smale reported from Berlin, and Rick Lyman from Ljubljana, Slovenia. Reporting was contributed by Somini Sengupta from the United Nations; Palko Karasz from Graz, Austria; Emmarie Huetteman from Salzburg, Austria; Barbara Surk and Kristina Bozic from Ljubljana; and Bostjan Videmsek from Obredje, Slovenia.
byline.original: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, ALISON SMALE and RICK LYMAN

abstract: Sec of State John Kerry announces United States will increase number of refugees it accepts from current annual cap of 70,000 to 100,000 by 2017; refugee advocacy groups say increase, while significant, will fall far short of needs of millions of people fleeing Syria, Iraq and other countries; US has accepted only around 1,500 Syrian refugees since conflict in that country began in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Under the plan, the limit on visas for refugees would be increased to 100,000 by 2017, a significant increase over the current annual cap of 70,000.

headline.main: U.S. Will Accept More Refugees as Crisis Grows
headline.print_headline: U.S. Will Accept More Refugees as Crisis Grows

snippet: Under the plan, the limit on visas for refugees would be increased to 100,000 by 2017, a significant increase over the current annual cap of 70,000.
